stream_context.summary: Kaze models and scripts the new “Space City” area (Course 14) of Return to Yoshi’s Island.  During the stream he prototypes a gramophone-shaped concert hall, a flying “space taxi” car to bridge an un-jumpable gap, tweaks stage lighting and reflective wall shaders, and discusses the mutant Yoshi boss concept drawn by Zeina.

development_findings.summary: First-star platforming for Space City is finished; visual polish is the current focus.
development_findings.quote: We got the platforming for the first star done; we’re still working on the visuals right now.

development_findings.summary: A concert hall shaped like a gramophone will be placed at the far end of the city.
development_findings.quote: I’m thinking there should be like some sort of concert hall here as well in the space city and I’m thinking it should be shaped like a gramophone.

development_findings.summary: A flying ‘space taxi’ will ferry the player across a gap that Mario cannot jump, unlocking after certain conditions.
development_findings.quote: I want there to be a space taxi going between these two. This is supposed to be a gap you can't jump.

development_findings.summary: Shy Guys are initially hiding; after the boss they emerge and drive the taxis, changing level navigation.
development_findings.quote: In the first act you can’t really get anywhere because all the Shy Guys are scared… during the second act, after you beat the boss, the Shy Guys are out and they're gonna drive these cars.

development_findings.summary: Zeina provided concept art for a mutant-Yoshi space boss to inhabit the level.
development_findings.quote: Zeina did some drawing. This was her idea for the mutant Yoshi—that’s the boss enemy here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rewrote movie-style lights, using a translation matrix tied to the camera to orient them correctly.
development_findings.quote: What I'm doing is taking the render matrix… using the Lakitu camera position to generate the matrix.

development_findings.summary: Reflective city walls are faked by offsetting UVs with camera movement; real cube-map reflections are impossible on N64.
development_findings.quote: We obviously do not have the computing power to actually reflect the stars.

development_findings.summary: Complex dynamic shadows are avoided to keep visual consistency and workload manageable.
development_findings.quote: If I add complex shadows in one place, I need them everywhere, and that’s going to be so much work.

development_findings.summary: Kaze’s engine profiling shows CPU logic at ~9 ms per frame on real hardware, allowing ~140 FPS theoretical ceiling.
development_findings.quote: My code takes 9 milliseconds to run on the N64.

context_findings.summary: Romhacking revenue is low; YouTube brought in $940 this month, $500 goes to his editor; Patreon is main income.
context_findings.quote: There’s just not really much money in ROM hacking… We made $940; I had to pay my editor like $500.

context_findings.summary: Since 2022 Kaze also works full-time as a professional programmer; RTYI is now a part-time endeavor.
context_findings.quote: In 2022 I got a job as a programmer as well, so now I also work as a programmer.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes constant requests for an unofficial PC port and wants no involvement with it.
context_findings.quote: Personally, I am not doing shit. I have nothing to do with the PC port. I want nothing to do with the PC port.

context_findings.summary: Kaze enjoys playful criticism: he likes ‘hating on things’ but feels guilty if others dog-pile.
context_findings.quote: I like hating on things, but I don't like if other people join me… then I feel like a bully.

biobak.summary: Polishes Kaze’s models, adds ideas, and re-UV-maps assets; Kaze notes his pay is not proportional to effort.
biobak.quote: Biobak goes over my models after I'm done and polishes them up, brings a lot of ideas and new concepts to the table.

badub.summary: Composes the soundtrack; Kaze states he cannot do music himself.
badub.quote: Yeah Badub is doing the music. I can't do music at all.

zeina.summary: Created the concept art for the mutant space-Yoshi boss.
zeina.quote: Zeina did some drawing… her idea for the mutant Yoshi.

key_stories.title: Designing the Space Taxi
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a way to cross a large gap in Space City without trivializing platforming.  He conceived a hover-car ‘space taxi’ that appears only after the boss, driven by newly courageous Shy Guys, to shuttle Mario between city sections.
key_stories.challenge: Keep the gap un-jumpable yet navigable later in the level.
key_stories.process: Modeled a low-poly flying car, discussed textures and polycount, and scripted its post-boss activation.
key_stories.outcome: A dynamic transport system that changes level flow between acts.
key_stories.key_quote: I want there to be a space taxi going between these two… during the second act, after you beat the boss, the Shy Guys are out and they're gonna drive these cars.

key_stories.title: Lighting Fix Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Stage spotlights were pointing the wrong way, breaking atmosphere.  Kaze live-debugged the render matrix, tied it to camera position, and restored correct illumination.
key_stories.process: Removed excess lights, added debug prints, rewrote matrix logic, and tested in-engine.
key_stories.outcome: Properly oriented lights that now highlight Mario and scenery.
key_stories.key_quote: Now Mario is being lit up by the light as intended.

key_stories.title: Mutant Space-Yoshi Boss Concept
key_stories.summary: Zeina proposed a mutated space-themed Yoshi as the course boss.  Kaze showcased her sketch, integrating it into the level’s narrative.
key_stories.challenge: Create a memorable boss suited to the space motif.
key_stories.process: Zeina sketched designs; Kaze reviewed them on stream and planned placement.
key_stories.outcome: Boss concept accepted; will drive level story and Shy Guy behavior.
key_stories.key_quote: This was her idea for the mutant Yoshi—that’s the boss enemy here.

open_questions.context: Only the concept art was shown; gameplay mechanics, attack patterns, and narrative role remain undefined.
questions: How will the mutant Yoshi fight differ from previous bosses?
What technical hurdles do you foresee implementing it?

open_questions.context: Gramophone-shaped hall is planned but details are loose.
questions: What role will the concert hall play in gameplay?
Will it host a star, a mini-game, or purely atmosphere?
How will audio and music tie into its design?

open_questions.context: Shy Guys hide in Act 1 and reappear post-boss to drive taxis.
questions: How is act switching technically handled in RTYI?
What other environmental changes occur between acts?
Why choose Shy Guys for this narrative device?

open_questions.context: Kaze fakes reflections via UV offsets; real cube-maps are impossible.
questions: Could low-res pre-rendered cube maps be feasible?
What frame budget do these fake reflections consume?
How does the team decide when to pursue visual tricks versus authenticity?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes payments are ‘not fair’ relative to effort and revenue is small.
questions: How does the team balance passion with financial reality?
Have you considered alternative funding models?
What lessons have you learned about monetizing ROM hacks?

open_questions.context: Community members offer to port RTYI; Kaze is resistant.
questions: What specific concerns make you oppose an official PC port?
